title: Gymnopédie No. 1

musicalLanguage.description: The first of Satie's three Gymnopédies (1888), among the most recognizable piano pieces in the repertoire. Marked 'Lent et douloureux' (slow and sorrowful), it floats a simple melody over gently alternating seventh chords. Music at the edge of silence.
musicalLanguage.structure: Simple binary: A section (two phrases) with variation and gentle return. The melody descends through D major over an unwavering harmonic pendulum between Gmaj7 and D major.
keyMoments: Measures 1-2: the bare chord introduction — two alternating harmonies that define the entire world of the piece
Measure 3: the melody enters on F#5, floating above the chords like a thought arriving
Measures 3-8: the first phrase — a gentle descent through D major, each note a small letting go
Measures 9-14: the second phrase descends further, reaching into the lower register
Measure 15: the melody returns to F#5, the same place but changed by the journey
teachingGoals: Evenness of the LH quarter-note pattern — bass note, then two chord tones, completely unhurried
RH legato: sustain each melody note fully, connecting them without accent
Balance: the melody must float above the quiet chords — present but weightless
Rhythmic independence: LH keeps steady pulse while RH sustains long notes
Pedaling: sustain pedal changes on beat 1 of each measure to let the chord bloom
styleTips: This piece is about what you don't play — the space between notes matters more than the notes themselves
No rubato. Satie despised rubato. Keep the tempo absolutely steady, like a clock
The entire dynamic range is pp to p. Never louder than a quiet conversation
Think of each melody note as a droplet falling into still water
The LH chords should feel like breathing — in, out, in, out — endlessly

measures.teachingNote: The piece begins with the left hand alone. G major seventh chord: G in the bass, then B and D above. This chord will alternate with D major throughout. Play each note evenly — quarter, quarter, quarter — like a gentle heartbeat.
D major chord answers: D in the bass, F# and A above. These two measures establish the harmonic world — Gmaj7 to D, back and forth, forever. The entire piece lives inside this pendulum.

The melody enters — F#5, high and clear, held for two beats. This is the first sound that sings. Let it float above the chord without any effort. The F# is the major seventh of G, creating a bittersweet shimmer.
The melody steps down one note to E5. Over the D major chord, E is the ninth — still floating, still unresolved. The descent has begun.
D5 — now the melody has found the tonic, but over the G chord it doesn't feel like home. This ambiguity is the soul of the piece.
B4 — the melody continues its gentle descent. Over the D chord, B is the sixth — warm, open. Each note falls naturally, like leaves.
A4 held, then the melody turns back up to B4 on beat 3 — the first sign of motion, a gentle upturn before the phrase ends. Like taking a breath.
The first phrase resolves on D5 — the tonic, over the tonic chord. A moment of rest. The phrase has traveled from F#5 down to A4 and settled on D5.
The second phrase begins. E5 — slightly lower than the first phrase's F#5 opening. The music is settling deeper, like sinking slowly into water.
A4 down to G4 — the melody reaches lower than before. G4 against the D chord creates a suspended feeling, a gentle sigh.
F#4 — the lowest point of the melody so far. One octave below where we started. The descent is complete.
A4 — the melody lifts slightly, preparing to return. The second phrase settles here, on the fifth of D major.

The melody returns to F#5 — back where it started, but the journey has changed how we hear it. This return is the emotional center of the piece. The same note, the same chord, but now it carries everything that came before.
E5 to D5 — the melody begins its final descent, this time moving a bit faster. Two notes in one measure instead of one.
D5 — settling toward home. The melody has made its final descent and arrives on the tonic.
The final note — D4, one octave lower. The melody dissolves into the chord. Let the sound fade to nothing. The piece doesn't end — it simply stops being heard.

source: Arrangement: AI Jam Session. Based on Erik Satie's Gymnopédie No. 1 (1888).
